Use this script to identify duplicates, then remove them:
python3 script.py filename

'''
import pprint
import sys

with open(sys.argv[1], 'r') as f:
    lines = f.readlines()

enable = []
disable = []
count = {}
for line in lines:
   if line.startswith('enable'):
       line = line.strip()
       word = line[7:]
       enable.append(word)
       count[word] = 1 if word not in count else count[word] + 1
   if line.startswith('disable'):
       line = line.strip()
       word = line[8:]
       disable.append(word)
       count[word] = 1 if word not in count else count[word] + 1

print('\n Conflicts:')
for x in enable:
    if x in disable:
        print(x)

print('\n\n Duplicates:')
x = [ (x, count[x]) for x in count if count[x] > 1 ]
pprint.pprint(x)
'''

diff --git a/kickstart/files/kickstart.cfg b/kickstart/files/kickstart.cfg

 EOF
 
-ilog "Create systemd presets and set personality traits"

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: Hello, Peter, thank you for your thorough work on this. I have a few comments in-line.

doc/source/admin/networking/ovn/sriov.rs.message:
When using SR-IOV this mapping is there for a specific reason, and this was explained in this file here:
https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/charm-guide/+/859144/1/doc/source/admin/networking/ovn/sriov.rst#b80

It is connected to providing DHCP and Metadata to SR-IOV instances.
This is also available from `cat /sys/class/net/enp3s0f0/device/sriov_totalvfs`, which may be a more human friendly entry-point.
Comparing the issuing of `sudo netplan apply` to "restart the network" does not do Netplan justice, it does attempt to only make changes where necessary and otherwise keep things running.

The port associated with the instance is not an ovn external port, so the text in this headline would be incorrect.

You are creating an OpenStack Neutron port with VNIC type `direct`.

The mention of the external port would also be incorrect in this context.

Neutron and the charms take care of all of this automatically and the end user visible operations boil down to:

1) Configure appropriate bridge mappings (see comment at the beginning of the file)
2) Enable DHCP on the subnet in Neutron.
3) Ensure one of the named applications of the ovn-chassis or ovn-dedicated-chassis charm in the Juju model has `prefer-chassis-as-gw` set to 'True'. (ref https://opendev.org/openstack/charm-deployment-guide/commit/2b6586af463b9cbaa366beedc565993c404af919)

Referring to external documentation to explain what is going on under the hood is great, but we kind of need to explain what they should do to make use of it first?

nit: There are specific IPv4 and IPv6 blocks specifically for documentation, and IMHO it would be better to use those.

These are documented by IANA [0][1][2][3]

0: https://www.iana.org/assignments/iana-ipv4-special-registry/iana-ipv4-special-registry.xhtml
1: https://www.iana.org/go/rfc5737
2: https://www.iana.org/assignments/iana-ipv6-special-registry/iana-ipv6-special-registry.xhtml
3: https://www.iana.org/go/rfc3849

A cloud may have multiple provider networks configured, so "external subnet" would not be precise in all circumstances.  Perhaps something like ... enabled on the subnet associated with the network used in the port create command above ?

To test DEB and RPM package: EITHER succesfully compile each of these packages, apply them in a CentOS and Debian environment and successfully run "auditd" app provided by the package (that uses using the default "docker.io/starlingx/stx-audit:stx.6.0-v1.0.3") image) OR create one AIOSX Debian and one AIOSX CentOS using images with this change present and successfully run "auditd" app present in the deploy. Consensus is we should stick with the 200 response in the code.
LGTM
Hm, it seems like in case of Kuryr we have return codes hidden behind openstacksdk, but please ping me on the patch changing them so we can run Kuryr tests on it.

I would argue that the code is wrong here.
Those put calls are all asynchronous, so should be returning 202.
Should api-ref/source/v2/quota.inc be updated as well?
Just to make sure I understand it well, do you mean that we should update the code to return 202 instead of 200, for these calls?

Yeah, that is what I am questioning. These PUT calls are asynchronous calls, for example update listener will go into a PENDING state and require a driver call and updates to the amphora instances when a TLS certificate is updated.
Much like the create calls are async and return 202 because of it.

The API reference is supposed to be the single-point-of-truth and in this case I think it may be right and the code wrong.

Changing the return code will break some SDKs, which check current return code. Example given: https://github.com/ovh/gophercloud/blob/master/openstack/loadbalancer/v2/l7policies/requests.go#L222

I guess they'll have to add 202 and when done we'll be able to change Octavia API.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
The hardcoded pollsters are grouped into namespaces, which enables the operator to create them based on the namespaces provided to the
'AgentManager'. On the other hand, the dynamic pollsters are always instantiated, independent of the provided namespaces (as long as they are placed in the `pollster.d` folder).

Therefore, it is not possible to enable/disable dynamic pollster based on the pollster group namespace that is configured in the `AgentManager`.

This configuration won't work for eBGP sessions. You need to apply incoming and outgoing filters. It might be simpler to just not require policies at all:

    no bgp ebgp-requires-policy

See more: https://docs.frrouting.org/en/latest/bgp.html#clicmd-bgp-ebgp-requires-policy

Would it make sense to allow peering with multiple neighbors?
For example, peering with two top-of-rack or provider edge routers.
Here you've set a conditional that password may or may not be set. In the devstack plugin however it is always set to md5.

Note that IPv4 is on by default even if the address-family block is not defined.
You may want to add the following to disable IPv4 by default:

    no bgp default ipv4-unicast

The local BGP daemon will accept any advertised IP prefixes from its neighbors and install them in the kernel routing table. This might likely pose a great security risk.

Consider filtering all received routes. There are various ways to accomplish this such as via route-map or prefix-list.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: Is there a review with this commit available for my reference?

Since the commit of meta-lat is not available the meta-lat layer upstream, so we have not sent the pull-request and just merge it into the internal repo branch.
I just copy the patch of meta-lat as follows:


Issue: CGTS-37459

For Redfish Subcloud Install it needs a small customizable initramfs
less than 80M.
Now we add a task to create this mini initramfs and compress it with
lzma format.
The detailed steps are as follows:
 1.Decompress the normal initramfs generated by lat with the yaml file.
 2.Drop rt kernel modules, __pycache__ directories, local entries...
 3.Generate the new initrd and compress it using xz command

Install the mini initrd into the /var/miniboot direcotry for rootfs,
and WRCP team will use it after the controller-0 node installation
during Redfish Subcloud boot.

Signed-off-by: Zhixiong Chi <zhixiong.chi@windriver.com>
---
 .../genimage/files/genimage/genimage.py       | 53 +++++++++++++++++++
 1 file changed, 53 insertions(+)

diff --git a/recipes-support/genimage/files/genimage/genimage.py b/recipes-support/genimage/files/genimage/genimage.py
index 58c144a..e15103e 100644
--- a/recipes-support/genimage/files/genimage/genimage.py
+++ b/recipes-support/genimage/files/genimage/genimage.py
@@ -1004,6 +1004,58 @@ class GenExtDebImage(GenImage):
                 utils.boot_sign_cmd(gpgid, gpgpassword, gpgpath, image)
             return
 
+    @show_task_info("Create Debian Miniboot Initramfs")
+    def do_ostree_mini_initramfs(self):
+        # If the Initramfs is generated, reuse it
+        image_name = "{0}-{1}.cpio.gz".format(deb_constant.DEFAULT_INITRD_NAME, self.machine)
+        image = os.path.join(self.deploydir, image_name)
+
+        if not os.path.exists(os.path.realpath(image)):
+            logger.error("External Debian Initramfs %s doesn't exist", image)
+            sys.exit(1)
+
+        logger.info("Reuse existed Initramfs for miniboot")
+
+        miniboot_initramfs = os.path.join(self.deploydir, "miniboot_rootfs")
+        if os.path.exists(miniboot_initramfs):
+            utils.remove(os.path.join(miniboot_initramfs), recurse=True)
+        utils.mkdirhier(miniboot_initramfs)
+
+        # extract the stardard initramfs and remove the unneeded files
+        cmd = "cd %s && gzip -d --stdout %s | cpio -i -d -H newc" % (miniboot_initramfs, image)
+        utils.run_cmd_oneshot(cmd)
+
+        # Removing (not needed for initial boot):
+        # These are found by examination via ncdu:
+        # - rt kernel modules
+        # - all __pycache__ directories
+        # - locale entries - we are using the default "C" locale for initial boot
+        # - vim - no need for an editor
+        cmd = "cd %s && rm -rf lib/modules/5*rt*amd64 && rm -rf usr/bin/vim.basic " % miniboot_initramfs
+        cmd += " && rm -rf usr/share/locale/* && rm -rf usr/share/info/* "
+        cmd += " && find . -type d -name '__pycache__' -print0 | xargs -0 rm -rf "
+        utils.run_cmd_oneshot(cmd)
+
+        miniboot_imagename = "initrd-mini"
+        miniboot_imagedir = os.path.join(self.target_rootfs, "var/miniboot")
+        utils.mkdirhier(miniboot_imagedir)
+        miniboot_image = os.path.join(miniboot_imagedir, miniboot_imagename)
+
+        cmd = "cd %s && find . 2>/dev/null | cpio -o -H newc -R root:root | xz -9 --format=lzma > \"%s\"" % \
+            (miniboot_initramfs, miniboot_image)
+        utils.run_cmd_oneshot(cmd)
+
+        if os.path.exists(os.path.realpath(miniboot_image)):
+            if self.data['gpg']['grub'].get('EFI_SECURE_BOOT', 'disable') == 'enable':
+                utils.run_cmd_oneshot("chmod 777 %s" % self.deploydir)
+                gpgid = self.data['gpg']['grub']['BOOT_GPG_NAME']
+                gpgpassword = self.data['gpg']['grub']['BOOT_GPG_PASSPHRASE']
+                gpgpath = self.data['gpg']['gpg_path']
+                utils.boot_sign_cmd(gpgid, gpgpassword, gpgpath, miniboot_image)
+
+            utils.remove(os.path.join(miniboot_initramfs), recurse=True)
+            return
+
 def _main_run_internal(args):
 
     pkg_type = GenImage._get_pkg_type(args)
@@ -1023,6 +1075,7 @@ def _main_run_internal(args):
         logger.debug("Create Target Rootfs: %s" % create.target_rootfs)
 
     create.do_ostree_initramfs()
+    create.do_ostree_mini_initramfs()
 
     # WIC image requires ostress repo
     if any(img_type in create.image_type for img_type in ["ostree-repo", "wic", "iso", "ustart", "vmdk", "vdi", "pxe"]):

This change is required for implementation of cluster downscaling functionality into the ovn-central charm.

Thank you for working on this, Martin!

I have a couple comment on the approach:
All of the members of the ovn-central Juju application does already have a local clustered copy of the OVN NB and SB databases.  Would it not be possible for the charm to get all the information it needs from this local copy at runtime?  I would avoid storing state information in charm/juju whenever possible as it could quickly go out of sync, and cache validation is hard.

If it turns out that it is necessary, I would preform the information gathering in the charm and not the interface.  Let the interface methods focus on understanding the relation data, and let the charm code focus on dealing with the workload.  There is also a rich set of library functions for OVS/OVN in charm-helpers [0].

0: https://github.com/juju/charm-helpers/tree/master/charmhelpers/contrib/network/ovs

> > Would it not be possible for the charm to get all the information it needs from this local copy at runtime?
> 
> The aim of this change is to allow ovn-central units to link juju identities of other cluster members (e.g. "ovn-central/2") to their identities in the Southbound and Northbound OVN clusters (e.g. "ff4e" and "a31c"). Right now, each unit can use their local copy of sb/nb database to see who else is in the cluster with them. However the sb/nb databases contain only the "Server ID" (afaik).
> 
> So lets say there are 3 units, ovn-central/{0,1,2}, (for simplicity lets deal with SB cluster only).
> 
> ovn-central/0 can look at the SB DB and see that there are 3 members:
> * ac43 (self)
> * 124e
> * 68ff
> 
> ovn-central/0 can tell which "Server ID" is its own (ac43) but it can't tell which Server ID belongs to "ovn-central/1" and which to "ovn-central/2"
> 
> With this change, it can use relation data shared by other units to make that connection.

In the database the ID is stored along with the peer IP address [0] which you could use to map to the related units. This information is also available in the cluster status, example:
$ sudo ovn-appctl -t /var/run/ovn/ovnnb_db.ctl cluster/status OVN_Northbound
6d2d
Name: OVN_Northbound
Cluster ID: 7da0 (7da0a998-856a-4062-bf26-15efb72984ba)
Server ID: 6d2d (6d2d760f-fc9b-4ac6-9e1c-b2f7e5001e19)
Address: ssl:10.247.39.250:6643
Status: cluster member
Role: follower
Term: 3
Leader: 0013
Vote: 0013

Election timer: 4000
Log: [13, 13]
Entries not yet committed: 0
Entries not yet applied: 0
Connections: ->0000 ->0000 <-0013 <-cdd3
Disconnections: 0
Servers:
    0013 (0013 at ssl:10.247.39.201:6643) last msg 1086 ms ago
    cdd3 (cdd3 at ssl:10.247.39.83:6643) last msg 395956 ms ago
    6d2d (6d2d at ssl:10.247.39.250:6643) (self)
    
0: https://www.openvswitch.org/support/dist-docs/ovsdb.5.txt

> >  I would avoid storing state information in charm/juju whenever possible as it could quickly go out of sync, and cache validation is hard.
> 
> In this case the only data that's stored in the relation is the NB and SB Server ID (One pair in each unit's bucket). IMO this is pretty permanent data but I might be wrong. Is there a scenario in which "Server ID" of the unit changes?

If the human operator is forced to have a unit leave and rejoin the cluster it would generate a new ID, yes. Having to update the relation data in addition to salvaging a cluster would just add to the burden on the human operator when it is not strictly necessary.

> > If it turns out that it is necessary, I would preform the information gathering in the charm and not the interface.
> 
> My intention was to abstract the logic (described above) into the interface and let charm simply collect the information it needs (map of "juju unit names" and related "Server IDs") via simple property (peer_cluster_ids). I think this fits the idea of "letting the interface methods focus on understanding the relation data" but if you still think that it should be moved to the charm code then it can be also done that way.

Per the discussion above I don't think we would need to store this data on the relation, but if we did, I would have done the interaction with the payload in the charm code. The charm code has superior knowledge about which version the payload has, and what rules apply for interacting with specific versions etc. etc, the interface does not and should not need to know these kinds of details.

> Would it not be possible for the charm to get all the information it needs from this local copy at runtime?

The aim of this change is to allow ovn-central units to link juju identities of other cluster members (e.g. "ovn-central/2") to their identities in the Southbound and Northbound OVN clusters (e.g. "ff4e" and "a31c"). Right now, each unit can use their local copy of sb/nb database to see who else is in the cluster with them. However the sb/nb databases contain only the "Server ID" (afaik).

So lets say there are 3 units, ovn-central/{0,1,2}, (for simplicity lets deal with SB cluster only).

ovn-central/0 can look at the SB DB and see that there are 3 members:
* ac43 (self)
* 124e
* 68ff

ovn-central/0 can tell which "Server ID" is its own (ac43) but it can't tell which Server ID belongs to "ovn-central/1" and which to "ovn-central/2"

With this change, it can use relation data shared by other units to make that connection.

>  I would avoid storing state information in charm/juju whenever possible as it could quickly go out of sync, and cache validation is hard.

In this case the only data that's stored in the relation is the NB and SB Server ID (One pair in each unit's bucket). IMO this is pretty permanent data but I might be wrong. Is there a scenario in which "Server ID" of the unit changes?

> If it turns out that it is necessary, I would preform the information gathering in the charm and not the interface.

My intention was to abstract the logic (described above) into the interface and let charm simply collect the information it needs (map of "juju unit names" and related "Server IDs") via simple property (peer_cluster_ids). I think this fits the idea of "letting the interface methods focus on understanding the relation data" but if you still think that it should be moved to the charm code then it can be also done that way.

> There is also a rich set of library functions for OVS/OVN in charm-helpers

Thanks, I'll look into it, this would probably be better way than executing `ovs-appctl` and parsing the output.

Thanks for the detailed feedback.
I considered using the IP initially but I thought that this approach would be more explicit. I was also bit afraid of potential mess if the OVN cluster was created in other juju space (subnet) than the peer relation was using but I double checked and it wont be a problem since the OVN cluster is using, for its configuration, IPs gathered via the peer relation.

I agree with you then that this change to the interface is not necessary and the charm can infer juju identity based on the IPs of the other cluster members.

swift/container/sharder.py.message:
I think multiple value return (success, warnings) is a good pattern for a task that can pass/fail but also wants to describe the specifics in more detail.

This adapter pattern does a good job showing we:

increment attempt
*make the attempt*
log warnings
increent success/failure

... and that book keeping looks good pulled out-side of and around the method that has to *do* the audit

I think this *behavior* is *so* interesting the "return early" pattern actually makes more sense.  We just *don't* do an audit if we don't have an OSR - and that's really the ONLY time we can "fail" to audit.

ok so returning warnings is the game-changer: when the "error" condition occurs we can return early from this method, which allows a cleaner exit from the method later.

+1 !

I'm not sure to what degree it is a "style rule", but I always expect to look up in the file for helper methods called from a method (but I know I often need to look down), particularly when there is only one call chain, I expect it to go up the file.

Here we now have some sub-methods above and some below _audit_shard_container - could we shift _do_audit_shard_container and _reclaim_shard_ranges above?

First of all, Ia3f414c4b9b0829f60 only adds the creator role to the cinder service. It does not add the role to the users that tempest uses when running tests.

There is a patch that tells tempest to include the create role, and that's I2023df6ce212bd9c455fa04a43419c6760e22267. You can see that here [1]

[1] https://storage.gra.cloud.ovh.net/v1/AUTH_dcaab5e32b234d56b626f72581e3644c/zuul_opendev_logs_728/855272/1/check/cinder-tempest-plugin-lvm-lio-barbican/72821f7/controller/logs/tempest_conf.txt

But, notice auth/tempest_roles *only* lists creator, and it doesn't include the member role. This causes lots of stuff the fail, and it looks to be the source of the 403 error thrown by swift in the c-bak log [2].

[2] https://storage.gra.cloud.ovh.net/v1/AUTH_dcaab5e32b234d56b626f72581e3644c/zuul_opendev_logs_728/855272/1/check/cinder-tempest-plugin-lvm-lio-barbican/72821f7/controller/logs/screen-c-bak.txt

Looking at tempest itself, it seems if auth/tempest_roles is configured then it assumes *all* the roles are listed. You don't get the member role for free unless auth/tempest_roles is left blank.

My conclusion is that [1] may be well intended, but it ends up limiting tempest to only the creator role, and that doesn't work because tempest also needs the member role. That's why this .zuul.yaml had to override the setting, to ensure both roles are present.

sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/openstack/co.message: this appears to affect the spacing based on what other periodic tasks set - should this be min(DEFAULT_INTERVAL, spacing) ?

The idle_for interval is the minimum interval that the system will 'sleep' until the next wake-up to execute an audit. So, imagine that if there is an audit with an interval that is less than the DEFAULT_INTERVAL (60"), the system will need to wake up before the DEFAULT_INTERVAL. That's why the idle_for needs to be the minimum value between all the audit intervals (as it's set now).
recommend investigation into integration of olso_service library (including PeriodicTasks) as standard library is likely to be more robust and maintained going forward.

zuul/executor/client.py.message:
This is currently adding the full parent span info to the build request which is not necessary for creating a child span on an executor. The information about the parent span could be smaller e.g. similar to the W3C trace context:

[0] https://www.w3.org/TR/trace-context/
should the span info be added to the build params?
I guess it depends if we add the full span info - in which case I'd say yes - or just propagate some kind of traceparent identifier which could be small enough to be part of the build request itself.
Attributes should be added when ending the span and not at the start. This way we don't have to store duplicate data in Zookeeper.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: I picked this change and verified that it fixes the build break

Thank you, Ananya :)

Voted -1 simply to mark this patch as "requires more work".

Some requests:

* Since ID is already part of the resource dict that is returned by the module, we can safely drop dedicated id attributes in self.exit_json() calls. We will not loose data and we break backward compatibility anyway.

* Ensure RETURN docs and self.exit_json() statements match. / For example, not all attributes returned by a module are of 'type: str'. Please refer to openstacksdk's resource objects to find the actual types. / Some branches do not return a stack object, so 'returned: always' is not true.

* Version checks are no longer necessary since we globally require openstacksdk >=0.99.0 anyway.

* Check manual error handling or parameter checking code can be moved to argument_spec or module_kwargs. module_kwargs allows to define dependencies between module options such as mutually_exclusive, required_together, required_if and much more: https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/dev_guide/developing_program_flow_modules.html#argument-spec-dependencies

* A couple of self.conn.get_*/delete_*/... functions can be replaced with their self.conn.orchestration.* counterparts

* When a resource exist and should be deleted (absent), then pass the resource to the delete_* function, not its name. Passing a name requires openstacksdk to find that resource again, doing a unnecessary api call, because we queried the resource before.

* Calling get_stack after self.conn.create_stack is not necessary because the latter already does that: https://opendev.org/openstack/openstacksdk/src/commit/9fa6603d4e5104fb33e3688967cd128c0b8ad019/openstack/cloud/_orchestration.py#L95

* _system_state_change returns False when stack is present but that is not true, it will update the stack. 

The following list of suggested changes is optional but much appreciated:

* Sorting module options in DOCUMENTATION, attributes in RETURN, entries in argument_spec and expected fields in integration tests will make reviewing easier and faster.

* We should document which attribute cannot be updated in DOCUMENTATION variable. For example, insert 'This attribute cannot be updated.' to DOCUMENTATION like we did for the server module and others.

* EXAMPLES for our modules (and Ansible's own modules) consist of a list of tasks. They do not contain YAML directives end marker line (---) and do not define playbooks (e.g. hosts keyword). They shall be simple, e.g. do not do fancy loops, heavy use of variables or use Ansible directives for no apparent reason such as ignore_errors or register.
addressed the priority tasks. I'll create a follow up patch for the documentation improvement
done for removing ID in exit_json, return values doc and version check. Working on the rest
Latest patchset is rebased on top of master, fixes linter issues, simplified examples and sorted return values.

Latest patchset drops 'id' from RETURN, calls to_dict(computed=False) before return stack and reverted self.conn.orchestration.delete_stack back to self.conn.delete_stack. The cloud layer delete_stack waits for the stack to reach status DELETE when wait is true which proxy layer's delete_stack does not to.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
I think this is not accurate. The function _lb_delete is called within try/except Exception, and in case of whatever exception happening in that function it sets the status to ERROR, not PENDING_DELETE.

So, this patch is avoiding to set the loadbalancer to ERROR while it could be properly deleted, as if the LS or LR is no longer there, there is no need of removing the lb from it
You are right! I was thinking on the trigger of this issue when wrote the title. I also refactor first paragraph to clarify. thx

ovn_octavia_provider/helper.py.message: I'm not sure I understand what's the point of raising error in case if any of the resources which should be deleted is already gone. Shouldn't we simply ignore all RowNotFound exceptions in this case?
ok, I got it now, thx

Yes, the main target with this patch is to delete the LB when a RowNotFound over a LsLbDel or LrLbDel is triggered. Currently, LsLbDel, LrLbDel and the most important command LbDel are included in the same transaction. As it is a single transaction, in case of any RowNotFound, we leave leftover of all types (LsLb, LrLb) and the most important one, the LB is not deleted reporting an ERROR status to the upper layer. With this patch we will "ignore" all RowNotFound as you propose, but we make sure not to leave leftover LsLb or LrLb and keeping the ERROR status case if the failed command is the LbDel, raising the exception ---> ERROR status, just to inform the upper layer (Octavia API)
